testimony.name: Lydia Andre
key_points: The trickle-down supply-side concept doesn't work
Local control should not be removed from neighborhoods
One-size-fits-all approach doesn't work for every neighborhood
Preserving neighborhood character and quality of life should be prioritized
The market has not succeeded in creating affordable housing
Open space is crucial to neighborhoods
The AMI numbers in the proposal don't match the actual income levels of New Yorkers most in need
The incentives for income averaging are unclear
The proposal needs improvement to better serve all New Yorkers

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: For the life of me, I can't understand why we are not mandating affordable housing
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote directly relates to the UAP element, which is about creating affordable housing. The speaker is criticizing the proposal for not mandating affordable housing, which is a key aspect of the UAP.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Right now, I see that the m AMI numbers you're using in this proposal don't jive with the actual income levels of New Yorkers in most need of affordable housing.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote refers to the Area Median Income (AMI) levels used in the proposal, which is a key component of the UAP. The speaker is criticizing the AMI levels as not accurately reflecting the needs of New Yorkers who need affordable housing.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: And for the life of me, I don't really see the incentives for the income averaging that you're talking about.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote likely refers to the income averaging aspect of the UAP, which allows for a range of income levels in affordable housing units. The speaker is expressing skepticism about the incentives for this approach.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: I don't think there's a one size fits all to every neighborhood.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: While not directly mentioning town center zoning, this quote suggests opposition to a uniform approach to zoning, which could include the town center zoning proposal. The speaker is advocating for neighborhood-specific approaches rather than a citywide policy.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: And preserving neighborhood character and quality of life for neighborhoods should be at the top of your list in addition to creating affordable housing.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote relates to the town center zoning proposal, which aims to create mixed-use neighborhoods. The speaker is emphasizing the importance of preserving existing neighborhood character, which could be seen as opposition to the changes proposed in the town center zoning element.
